inputs.prompt: Create an extreme close up view of the main element in the scene. Studio scene with a white background.
Create a low view, super-wide shot of the main subject in this scene. Studio scene with a white background.
Side view of the main subject in the scene. Studio scene with a white background.
Create an extreme wide shot from behind the subject near the passenger side of the back rims. Studio scene with a white background.

STEP 1: ANALYZE BOTH IMAGES
Before crafting the prompt, analyze both images to understand:


Camera distance (wide shot, medium, close-up, extreme close-up, macro)
Camera angle (low-angle, high-angle, eye-level, overhead, Dutch, worm's eye, bird's eye)
Camera position relative to subject (front, side profile, 3/4 view, back, overhead)
Framing (full body, torso, chest-up, face only, detail/macro)
Subject position and pose
Lighting setup and direction
Background elements and depth
Focal length characteristics (wide-angle distortion vs telephoto compression)

STEP 2: DETERMINE CAMERA MOVEMENT
Based on the differences between images, identify the primary camera movement:


Distance change: Dolly-in (closer) or Dolly-out (farther)
Vertical angle change: Tilt up/down or Crane up/down
Horizontal angle change: Pan left/right or Orbit/Arc around subject
Height change: Crane/Pedestal up or down
Lateral movement: Truck/Track left or right

STEP 3: OUTPUT ONLY THE PROMPT
Do not include explanations, commentary, or additional text.
Output ONLY the transition prompt in this format:


[CAMERA MOVEMENT] from [START POSITION] to [END POSITION]. Subject remains stationary and consistent throughout. Camera [MOVEMENT VERB] fluidly, maintaining [FOCUS BEHAVIOR] on [KEY ELEMENT]. Lighting stays constant, background [BACKGROUND BEHAVIOR]. [TECHNICAL SPECS]. --no [NEGATIVE ELEMENTS]

Core Principle

For transitions where the subject/scene remains consistent and only the camera position changes, use this structured approach to ensure smooth, cinematic results.


Prompt Structure Template

[CAMERA MOVEMENT] from [START POSITION] to [END POSITION]. Subject remains stationary and consistent throughout. Camera [MOVEMENT VERB] fluidly, maintaining [FOCUS BEHAVIOR] on [KEY ELEMENT]. Lighting stays constant, background [BACKGROUND BEHAVIOR]. [TECHNICAL SPECS]. --no [NEGATIVE ELEMENTS]

Component Breakdown

1. CAMERA MOVEMENT TYPES


Dolly-in/Push-in: Camera moves forward toward subject
Dolly-out/Pull-back: Camera moves backward away from subject
Orbit/Arc: Camera circles around subject (specify left/right)
Tilt: Camera angles up or down on fixed position
Pan: Camera swivels left or right horizontally
Crane/Pedestal: Camera moves vertically up or down
Tracking/Trucking: Camera moves parallel to subject

2. POSITION DESCRIPTORS


Distance: wide shot, medium shot, close-up, extreme close-up, macro
Angle: low-angle, high-angle, eye-level, overhead, Dutch angle, worm's eye view, bird's eye view
Framing: full body, three-quarter, torso, chest-up, face, detail

3. MOVEMENT VERBS (choose intensity)


Slowly, steadily, smoothly, gradually, fluidly
Rapidly, dynamically, swiftly
Elegantly, dramatically, confidently

4. FOCUS BEHAVIOR


Sharp focus throughout
Rack focus from [A] to [B]
Maintains focus on [element]
Shallow depth of field
Deep focus
Progressive focus shift

5. BACKGROUND BEHAVIOR


Stays consistent
Blurs to bokeh
Sharpens into view
Fades to [color]
Remains sharp throughout

6. TECHNICAL SPECS (standard cinematic quality)


Cinematic depth of field
Stable gimbal/dolly movement
Professional commercial grade
24fps (or 30fps, 60fps for slow-motion feel)
Clean sensor, no grain (or "film grain" if desired)


Example Prompts by Movement Type

DOLLY-IN (Wide → Close-up)


Smooth camera dolly-in from wide establishing shot to extreme close-up. Subject remains stationary. Camera pushes forward steadily, transitioning focus from [background element] to [detail]. Lighting stays constant, background softly blurs to bokeh. Cinematic depth of field, stable gimbal movement, 24fps. --no shake, cuts, warping, distortion

DOLLY-OUT (Close-up → Wide)


Smooth camera pull-back from extreme close-up to wide establishing shot. Subject remains centered and stationary. Camera retreats steadily, revealing environment progressively. Focus maintains on subject while background sharpens into view. Even lighting, cinematic depth of field, 24fps. --no shake, cuts, jump, warping

ORBIT (Circular movement)


Smooth camera orbit from front view to side profile. Subject remains stationary at center. Camera arcs left fluidly in 90-degree rotation, maintaining constant distance and eye-level angle. Lighting stays consistent, sharp focus throughout. Gimbal stabilized circular tracking, 24fps. --no shake, warping, speed changes, distortion

TILT (Vertical angle change)


Smooth camera tilt from low-angle to high-angle. Subject remains stationary. Camera tilts upward gradually, shifting perspective from worm's eye view to bird's eye view. Distance stays constant, lighting consistent. Stable tripod tilt, cinematic framing, 24fps. --no shake, panning, horizontal movement, warping

PAN (Horizontal swivel)


Smooth camera pan from left profile to right profile. Subject remains stationary. Camera swivels horizontally across 180 degrees, maintaining constant distance and eye-level. Sharp focus throughout, even lighting. Fluid tripod pan, 24fps. --no shake, tilting, vertical movement, cuts

CRANE UP/DOWN


Smooth camera crane from ground-level to overhead view. Subject remains stationary at center. Camera elevates vertically, angle shifting from eye-level to bird's eye view. Distance adjusts proportionally, lighting consistent. Stabilized crane movement, 24fps. --no shake, lateral movement, warping, distortion

Key Rules for Camera-Only Transitions

Always specify subject remains stationary - This prevents unwanted morphing
Describe start AND end positions clearly - Gives model clear targets
Use specific movement verbs - "Dolly-in" is clearer than "moves closer"
Lock down what DOESN'T change - Lighting, subject, clothing, expression
Include technical quality markers - Gimbal, 24fps, cinematic, stable
Negative prompts are critical - Prevents warping/morphing/distortion
Keep prompts under 75 words - Model weights early words heavier
One primary movement per transition - Don't combine dolly + pan + tilt

Advanced Techniques

Speed Ramping:
"Camera begins slow dolly-in, accelerates midway, then decelerates smoothly into final close-up"


Combined Movements (use sparingly):
"Camera dollies in while simultaneously tilting down, maintaining subject center-frame"


Focus Pulls:
"Rack focus from foreground [element] to background [element] as camera remains locked"


Lens Simulation:
"Wide-angle 24mm distortion gradually compresses to telephoto 85mm compression"



Critical Output Rule

OUTPUT ONLY THE PROMPT. NO EXPLANATIONS. NO COMMENTARY. NO ADDITIONAL TEXT.
